Hey voyagers,
/trv/ is a slow board, so don't expect immediate responses. CHECK THE CATALOG – you might find threads already discussing topics you're interested in.

Before asking for suggestions, tell /trv/ about your:
>Budget
>Interests
>Level of understanding of the local language(s)
This makes it easier to give quality advice. Of course, keep your posts travel related.

For all other matters:
General culture questions >>>/int/
Politics discussion >>>/pol/
Transportation discussion >>>/n/
Outdoors-related discussion >>>/out/

For more information about safety, planning and other miscellaneous topics, check out the pastebin in the next post:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2382305

You can get from one side of Israel to the other in a 6-7 hour drive.

There's a 1-3 hour drive to the Negev desert from Jerusalem. The Ramon crater is also pretty cool as desert settings go.

Also, Jerusalem has a nightlife scene that "competes" with Tel Aviv.

Since you're coming during "winterish" times, I highly recommend you go north and see Golan Heights. Amazing scenery and as a tourist, you will be welcome in the near Arab cities and experience some great food.

If you have a night in Tel Aviv, get some top-tier weed and go for a hipster culture and drinks spree.

I can find literally no genuine reviews or experiences on the internet about this.

Going to Brazil from Melbourne soon. Qatar airways with one stop in Doha is looking like the best option.

They offer, for only an extra $100, the option to stopover in a five-star hotel for a night in Doha. I figure its well worth it to visit to a country and region I would otherwise never go to.

My flight would land at 2am and my next flight leaves at 2am the next day. Is it worth it? Does anyone know if I'd have to checkout at 10am or something? Anyone ever been to Doha or done a stopover program with another airline?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I am NOT trans btw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2383232
Did it recently, it's good. Do two nights though, one will be a meme with the times you described. Hotels are really good if you choose the 5 star options, I stayed in the souq waqif one by Tivoli and it was lux. You can have a hotel guy drive you around the souq in a golf cart if you want, idk why you would tho. Qatar is fucking boring like the rest of the gulf excl. KSA, but you'll find enough to do in a day and a half. Spend your first day strolling round Doha and go to the museum of Islamic art and souq waqif, next day on a trip to the inland sea or the north south art thing in the desert. Country done.

posts.com:
I guess it depends on what you want out of your coffee. If you want the best of modern coffee, you could probably go to Sweden, Norway, Australia, even NYC. Here you’ll probably find lighter, more acidic coffees. Italy will give you an older, more classic experience, and the coffee will be more bitter and, yes, lower quality than the other countries I mentioned

I actually really liked the old school cafes, or kissaten, in Japan. Cafe de l’ambre in Tokyo or Otafuku or Hanafusa in Kyoto come to mind. They serve darker coffees, so they probably offer something more in line with a classic cafe experience than a trendy spot in Scandinavia or Australia

Finland had a period of prohibion and that of course spiked the use of coffee. It is a huge cultural thing too, I can't imagine Finland without people drinking this much of the stuff. posts.name: Anonymous

>>2375976
Can’t really comment on worst or best; but in relation to picrel; I genuinely, heart of hearts believe that they’re the best in the world just taking into account their fares.

I mean even now, I’m getting flights with Ryanair for $25. It’s not what it once was, I remember times where I’d fly return tickets across Europe for €20, significantly less than what it would cost to get the bus or train to the airport.

It’s a no-frills experience, don’t expect anything great, but it does what it says on the tin, which is get you from a-b.

Great thing about Ryanair too, I used to work in the aviation industry in Europe. Dealing with a lot of bigger legacy carriers, a technical issue, or something along those lines would normally result in passengers stranded for hours, sometimes overnight for the next possible flight or just an outright cancellation for days. Ryanair always had another plane to go within a couple of hours tops and I haven’t once witnessed anything otherwise.

>Why Taiwan ?
why not ? it's Asia on easy level, tons of friendly people, nicest expat community that isn't weeb or druggies or coomers

>No, seriously, why ?
Great emphasis on industry so all engineers are welcome
They recruit a lot of TEFL and it's relatively well paid compared to the average salary on the island, great if you don't have any student debt to deal with
Taipei is absolutely gorgeous, the skyline may not be up to standards compared to the megacities of Asia but it's a nice place with all the amenities of a world-class city
Rent is relatively cheap compared to the other big places in Asia, easily comparable to Thailand (albeit with a roughly 20% markup)
Street food is cheap and delicious
Taiwan has a rich and multicultural history that allows them to be ok with the concept of being a foreigner

>Is Taiwan the real China ?
No, ROC isn't the real china, it's an offshoot as much as the PRC is. Taiwan has been impacted by japanese culture a lot whereas the PRC modified radically china's culture through the cultural revolution. Both represent significant aspects of the Chinese civilization and you should go to both if you're truly interested.

>How can I immigrate/expatriate/live in Taiwan ?
Work Visa, Working Holiday Visas, Gold Card Visa, Student visa, and Chinese Student visa. and whatever investor scheme i can't be arsed to look up. Always make sure you consult your local Taiwanese embassy (likely referred as a taipei representative office in your country). Keep in mind the latter two make you eligible for a couple of grants and allow you to work (you need a work permit but it's easy to get).

>Where can I stay and have a nice time

A guy made a cool map on another thread.

>the problem with the taiwanese downtown is that it spans half the fucking city with many nevralgic centers (Dongmen, Ximen, 101, Technology Building, Main Station, Digital Plaza around Songjiang Nanjing etc.). So as long as you're within the city limits (even if you're not, you're never THAT far), It'll take you as much time to walk to the station than to get to your station of choice. I highly suggest living near the green line (so, the green zone) because that practically gets you anywhere and is well connected to the red Line (which basically covers the more expensive Da'an area). You could also consider living up north where the black area is. This is where a lot of older expats live, but i don't know much about it besides Yuanshan with its Maji Square (and its Triangle)

You want cheap but nice addresses, look around Wanshan and Zhongzheng District. If that's too much, you can still settle for something around Xindian without missing out on the rest of Taipei since it's not that far. Also, the 648 bus basically goes from the deeper end of xindian all the way to City Hall, so even if you're a cheap hack you can make do with that. Because yes, knowing how the buses work in Taipei will save you a *lot* of money.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2371940
A complicated question that highly depends on the skills you have, your ability to socialize and network with locals and your luck. For such questions i usually suggest you go there and find out provided you have some minimal amount of things you can bring to the table (such as some kind of professional experience in a field).

>>2374819
He's right you know. Countries, especially Asia, put a high emphasis on degrees when it comes to work visas. Sometimes having a degree is mandatory, and also having some work experience too. Also, maybe they don't even hire in your field, or you would need to speak mandarin to somehow level the field.

>>2375127
Taipei 101 is definitely worth visiting. There's also the linjiang night market nearby too. Also, elephant mountain is a bit of a climb but the view is worth it.

Also, Taipei main station has some very cool underground malls, more precisely Beimen Station. You can find lots of weeb stuff there as well as some nice goodies and souvenirs you can bring with you. In general, if you're not planning to go to Japan any time soon, Taiwan in general is a great source of weeb shit you can gift or keep for yourself.

All the night markets to visit are omnipresent on the internet so i won't bother you with them.

Definitely go to Ximending, it's a nice bustling neighborhood. There's also the Guanghua digital plaza if you're looking for electronics. Definitely haggle if you're there. They've got great deals.

The Gongguan river park is really nice this time of year, definitely rent some bikes and go there, it's really nice. The Gongguan area in general is my favorite, they've got the best all you can eat hotpots too and there's NTU too. Also, the neighborhood around Technology building (north of NTU and gongguan) is good looking with lots of cool restaurants.

I highly recommend the museums too. CKS memorial, palace museum, etc.

Oh and definitely try to escape taipei for an evening and plan a trip to Keelung.

just go with libgen using unblockit (google it). you've got both volumes. workbook and textbook
You don't need a dedicated grammar textbook for chinese. You can go with the HSK textbook (for simplified) or the NTNU traditional chinese textbook. Those are the ones people work with, meaning if you're looking to be taught later, the teachers will familiar with either one of those depending on where they're from.
When you learn a language like Chinese you're better off following the beaten path. Just do whatever the people around you do and stick to it.
Also, i don't think you should care about the difference until you get 2, 3 years unless there is an urgent need to improve. They don't give a fuck about you being the Jodie Foster of Chinese.


>>2379257
When I said there wasn't any tae kim equivalent i didn't mean that there weren't any textbooks you could check out. Tae Kim's grammar guide is dedicated to grammar because Japanese requires a rundown if you want to say even the simplest of shit. Also, "the nuance and subtleties" are irrelevant when you're a beginner. work on it hard for like a year and a half, get the basics. The only thing you have to worry about is to orally recognize the fucking words because chinese is spoken very fast outside of classes and the taiwanese have a lisp-y accent that can get very confusing. I mean fuck, just get your TONES right to start with. You'll sound like Tarzan but you'll at least be intelligible.

If you're going to Taipei ? Go to the NTNU (normal taiwan uni near Guting station) library and purchase "A course in Contemporary Chinese". It's the one I used to study, and it's basically THE standard traditional textbook here in Taiwan, and getting a physical copy along with the workbook is good advice.
You can find it on libgen too in the meantime. Don't waste your time learning simplified if you know you're going to taiwan. The switch is hard.

>>2379980
In practice, i know a few folks who did what you're planning to do. In theory, customs could refuse your entry if you're doing 1 week visa runs so you can come back right away. Always look like a tourist (shorts, sunglasses, hawaiian shirt) and never like a business man, deny all intents of work and business when asked.

As for work, you're not supposed to but they can't really check if everything's on the internet and your bank account is abroad. It'll only get dicey if you seek physical employment by being, for example, an english teacher, because there are a lot of snitches.

Also, make sure you never overstay, and always have a backup plan if you can't get in. A gf is usually needed since she could be the only one able to pack your shit and send it back to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

posts.com: What are some cool things I can do as a first time solo traveller in London? Is it worth taking the time to visit another city too? (Im in london for 4 days). posts.name: Anonymous

>>2382703

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2382705
I like a good mix of stuff, I like clubbing (though not sure how active london clubs will be during weekdays), Interested in war stuff, also like good food (who doesn't). I'm 23- will be staying in royal national hotel london.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2382708
As you're only in London for a short time you want to hit up the most fun spots, there's loads of pubs around, just head in and see if you like them, avoid anything with an Irish name as they're generic identikit pubs you find all around the world. Perhaps if you're staying central head to the punch & judy in covent garden, super central and pretty iconic, if you're looking for something a bit more exciting then close to where you're staying there's a pub called the griffin, it's an old school strip pub, decent pub prices plus you get women come around every 15 minutes with a pint glass, everyone sticks a pound in, she then gets up on stage, gets her kit off and then the next girl goes round with a glass, there's usually about 5-6 dances per hour so for £6 it's actually pretty good entertainment even if you're solo or have a few hours to kill, there's another one called browns near old street which is the same sort of deal but is more a club than pub, id give both a miss before 3pm though as you'll probably be one of a handful of blokes and it's a bit awkward being the old guy there.
For later in the evening fabric night club on a Friday night is pretty much the best night out you can have clubbing in London, it's drum & bass night and it's iconic, even if you don't like the music you'll still have a great time, lots of people go solo but if you don't fancy it jump onto meetup, there's always loads of people looking to go with a group.
If you're not around for Friday then ministry of sound is probably the most well known club in London and worth a visit, even during the week they do student nights so there's always something to do
Food wise there's loads of decent markets that during the week cater to the workers but do great food, the market bear Victoria station and borough market are ones you've probably heard about but worth a visit.
Other normie places to visit are the Churchill war rooms, Greenwich park & observatory, imperial war museum etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2382802
Also if you like Asian food there's a place called bang bang in colindale which is north west London, it's a huge food court with about 40 different stalls with food from all over Asia, it's well worth a visit, theres obviously China town in central London but that's just a tourist trap and the food is just the same shit you'd get from your local Chinese take away.
Camden town is also a normie meme, you'll probably end up there but it's just gotten shitter and shitter over the years, just full of smack heads and muggers now, go if you must but the food and clothes there are shit tier as they know they're not after repeat business they just serve the worst stuff to 1 off tourists.
If you are after a slightly fancier meal then I'd recommend any of the Hawksmoor restaurants, they have about 6 around the city and they're all good, mid priced but excellent quality
If you like middle Eastern food head to marble arch, it's the corner of Hyde park and go down Edgware road, any of the ranoush restaurants down there serve excellent middle Eastern food and god tier shawarmas, also pretty cheap about £5 each

Here's an anti-jet lag tip:
>set your watch to Japan time before take off
>if it's 11pm or 12am, go to sleep.
>doesnt matter if the plane hasnt taken off yet, or if they havent served food yet, go to sleep
>if you wake up and its only 3am or something, go back to sleep
>the airline will leave a note at your seat showing you missed your meal and they'll serve you whenever you want
>when all the morons on the plane are sleeping at 7am watch a movie or something
No more jetlag.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381954
The culture shock is going to be big, even if you lived in a big town in the U.S. Asian countries will seem pretty alien at first compared to European countries but it will be exciting. Don't stress too much. You will be in a school with peers as well who could become friends.

I will warn you though, don't rely on familiarity. My little brother is extremely well adjusted socially, has a hot girlfriend and can talk real smooth to bosses and strangers. Real likeable guy. After college he got an internship for some company in Shanghai so he worked there for like 7-8 weeks. The internship was set up by the school basically and he was placed in an apartment in the Baoshan district that is pretty trendy and popular with other schools for internships. I didn't have anything going on so I went to visit him for like 3-4 weeks. When I got to apartment that had like 250 residents, maybe 10-20 of those were foreigners there for internships. The foreigners were fucking uppity snobs from rich areas of London, India, U.S. etc and were pretty lame and didn't like my brother.

There was one kid there though who was a real interesting guy. Valedictorian, very likeable, and was probably on the spectrum that we hung out with all the time. The other foreigners didn't like him. Me, him and my brother were considered outcasts by people who spoke the same language. We are white and so were a good majority of the others but they wanted nothing to do with us. Here's the kicker though. The Chinese locals in the apartment loved us and didn't like the foreigners. They all hung out in their group while we would hang out with locals. That group closed themselves off to both foreigners and natives.

If you feel like you don't fit in with a group in your school, dont force it. There is likely someone else in the same position and you will get a more raw experience if you lean into the outside. In this case the locals treated that group like foreigners and they treated us like guests.

The one guy we met was invited into several peoples homes for dinner by the locals which didn't happen to me or my brother. Was cool seeing a picture of him in some warehouse eating eggs and tilapia that was raised in a 50 gallon drum with some random people he probably smiled at.

I rode BMX bikes with some Chinese BMX riders until 4am.

Little brother dated some tight little chinese chick whose mother ran the biggest shipping yard in Shanghai and whos father is a fighter jet pilot.

We were once at this club with other foreigners and this one chinese dude was trying to dance with this american girl. She got physically disgusted an ran away. She killed the vibe. I probably pointed at the guy and gave him a friendly "sly dog" smirk and kept dancing and kept everything cool. He then pointed at my american flag shorts and gave me a thumbs up and motioned to me to come hangout at his table and we drank and took pictures and shit. The other foreigners were staying in their group while the locals were offering us drinks and vibing. We were hanging out in probably like a $30k private booth while the foreigners stood around their little cuck stool drinking anti-freeze kek.

But yeah, where im going with this is that you are a foreigner. People might be curios. Don't use people who share the same language as a crutch. I had a great time hanging out with people who didn't understand a lick of english. Your body language, how you smile, laughter etc is universal. Don't worry too much about your trip. A friendly smile goes a long way. Worse case scenario, I will be there from the 9th through Mar 22nd and will try to hang out a few times or someone here can. I think you will be fine though.

everything you ever wanted is sitting on the other side of fear.
it's obviously natural that you're feeling nervous, but staying in the comfort zone of your small town isn't an option for you.
every great person in history has left their comfort blanket and embarked on some kind of adventure - i'm sure every single one of them had some nerves before setting off.
being nervous just shows you care and want to be prepared, which is a sign that you've made a good decision. if you weren't nervous at all, it'd probably be because you weren't serious in the first place.

if you want to be extra sure you will have mobile data, there are Japanese phone companies that will ship you a SIM card to your current address before you leave.
if you can't do this, don't worry about it. do you think you'll be the first foreigner who needs to get a new SIM card upon arriving in Japan?

posts.com:
>>2382903
It's possible, but it might not be easy or straightforward because you're relocating as a couple. I can't tell you the best route, but I can tell you what I did.

To teach in Japan without a master's degree, you generally have two options: teaching at an eikaiwa school or teaching as an ALT in public schools. You aren't likely to find a lot of eikaiwa in the countryside, so an ALT position would be the better bet for you. For that, you need to look for dispatch employers. There are a few companies out there that hire ALTs, but many of them require you to be in the country already. I initially applied to Interac, a dispatch company that hires from abroad and provides work visas. I told them the general geographic region I preferred, and that I wanted to live in a smaller town, and they obliged.

The issue that you'll likely face is that you're looking to relocate together, and as you might imagine, it's much harder to find small towns that want to hire two ALTs. That's not to say they don't exist at all, and there are some ways to get around that. For example, you might be assigned to neighboring towns (not so likely), or you might be assigned to a larger city nearby to which you can commute while living in a small town nearby. If one of you gets a job, the other one can apply for a spousal visa, but I don't know what the timeframe would look like on that, and it's possible that a spousal visa request could be denied, as ALT contracts usually only last for one year at a time (but are renewable).

Oh, one other thing to keep in mind is that in my experience, the dispatch company is more likely to honor your request of a rural town if you can speak Japanese somewhat well. Think about it from their perspective: if you can't speak Japanese, you could still get by without much support from the company in a big city, but in a small town, it's more likely you'll be requesting their aid for small things like getting mail redelivered.

>>2378143
You're wrong. You can get a room in Seville for like $400 a month, I know someone who is doing this. It's a nice college town, young sluts come from all over Europe on Erasmus.

If a Latino immigrant making 10€/hr picking strawberries can make it in Spain, you can too, ffs. You could get a room in a tier-one city like Madrid for like 700 bucks.

You just have to know where to look for an apartment. Don't use AirBnb for anything other than the short term. Go on local Facebook groups and ask where to get started looking.

If people find out you have a remote American income they'll be lining up to rent to you. I met a Brazilian guy willing to rent to me for $40 a night at the height of the tourist season in Barcelona. If you looked online you'd hardly be able to find anything for less than $200, if you were able to find anything at all. Wasn't a bad part of town either, even though in Spain "the bad part of town" is an absolute joke in terms of danger compared to the US, Latin America, France, etc.

You do have to be aware of scams. If a nigger starts video calling you asking for a deposit on a place you haven't been to, don't give him anything.

I've found that Spain is a nice middle ground for someone looking to live large on a remote income. It's a safe, clean white country that is full of attractive women, very cosmopolitan with a vast cultural wealth at the same time. The nightlife is out of this world. I was able to eat out twice a day and get drunk every night when I went, and I make less than $100k. Yes, it's difficult if you depend on the local economy to make a living, but if you make your money abroad it's an option that is definitely worth considering.

i could very well be wrong about this, but i was thinking about the splash conversion the other day and i started thinking about what the probability could be that 70+% of the ride will remain intact and i white pilled myself into believing that the chances are good.
here's why; first of all production of new animatronics is expensive, and i'm sure imagineers were aware that projection mapped heads on limited motion bodies arent as well received as even the older practical style animatronics by both enthusiasts and the general public. this is true about projections in general. my boomer relatives have even remarked about this when they rode frozen ever after and mickey's runaway. they agreed that great movie ride was better and their reason was that the animatronics werent "real" and they looked like screens.
splash is renowned for two things, the drop and the animatronic driven theming and storyline. in order for the conversion to live up to the standard of its counterpart, it would need to keep most of the animatronics or really shell out enough from the budget to have at least half as many which is still a lot. and they cant just make them all projection mapped it would be an underwhelming presentation in comparison to what the ride was before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378097
now add in the fact that most of the ride's layout lends itself to the way the indoor sets are built into the building. thats big money to change all that.
i think what we are likely to see in the end could be compared to what the skinning of Haunted Mansion into Holiday is like.
Most of the ride will remain the same and feel the same but the theming will be different. The America Sings animatronics will stay, the whole damn riverboat will stay, brer fox and bear animatronics could be repurposed but also could go completely but if they do go, those will be the tiana projection mapped ones that drive the story but they will be in the same spots as the old ones and all the sets will be in the same spots they will just be reskinned.
the reason i believe all this is not just because of the logistics of cost vs meeting high expectations but because it just would make more sense to do it that way, and keep the experience as familiar as possible while still transforming it into something new.if i'm wrong and this ride is frozen ever after 2.0 then i will at least be right about how it will be perceived by the public. many people didnt even know what maelstrom was called, and they only recalled some sort of boat ride at epcot that they mostly remembered as being in the mexico section. Splash has a bit higher status than that, and they know it. they are not even going to change it as much as they changed maelstrom, and i gotta admit when i ride it now, all im thinking about the whole time is "that's where the trolls were" and "thats where the polar bear was standing as you drifted backward and it disappeared into the darkness".
I think I'll be able to do the same with Splash as long as the layout and the placement of everything is the same.
And the riverboat. Just give me the fucking riverboat thats all i really ask.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378206
flume rides are relatively non-complicated ride systems which can be updated and refurbished fairly easily and inexpensively which is why so many parks have had the same flume rides for 40+ years.
Add in the fact that Hopkins rides still exists and manufactures parts and there is little reason why parks would replace these rides when they are still massively popular and can be maintained whenever they need to be for not a lot of effort or cost.
In the case of Splash its especially practical to preserve its ride system not only because of the way it was built into its surrounding structure but because the layout is a massive hit with the public and would be difficult to match if they were to come in with some water coaster or something that would shorten the length of the ride and take away from the compatibility for the rides theming to be in sync with the pace of the ride etc.
Replacing Splash's ride system would be a huge mistake and a costly one at that, even for disney.

>>2379557
>i think roller coasters are cooler than theming but theming for the roller coaster is ok but i dont really care about walking around in a themed park i'd rather go through an actual park
The people who go to theme parks to walk around and me immersed by theming really should consider going to actual parks (like national parks in the US). Immerse yourself in real natural beauty, not fake rock work. Some people go to Epcot just to walk around the themed countries and eat and drink and IMO that's not worth the admission price. You can do the same at the themed Vegas Strip casinos for free.

I think most of the general public doesn't care about theming. They're there for the rides. Disney World fans make a big deal about the resort as a whole and the non-park aspects, but none of that would exist without the theme parks. Over half of the parks are 1 day visitors from off property. They're not there to walk around and people watch, ride a couple rides and go back to the hotel, they're there all day to ride as many rides as possible. Coasters being among the most popular rides whether they're themed or not.

I think a little theming helps. For example, Steel Vengeance has a mining back story in the queue and its overall look fits the nearby themed frontier town. I think this works a lot better than a parking lot coaster. Cedar Point is unique in that it's on a peninsula surrounded by Lake Erie (and a marina entrance), has a giant sandy beach, and its marquee coasters offer fantastic views of these things.

>I heard they have the worse return tourist rate (5%) of the SEA countries. Why don't tourists return to Vietnam?
1. Most people who would do return trips after crossing off all the major sights from their list are either sex pests or resort tourists. Vietnam is garbage for both. The cooming offer is nowhere close to its neighbors and the beaches are frankly shit. While they can seem nice at a first glance, Vietnam is drowning in trash and has zero water pollution standards. You'll be frolicking in the waves and suddenly there's literal shit all around you.
2. People are often plain rude. There's little in the way of etiquette and the concept of disturbing others (which is generally a problem with SEA, but not to that level) does not exist in Vietnam at all. They'll spit, cut the line and play shitty Tik-Tok vids on full volume at 3AM on a night bus if they feel like it. Everyone working in the tourist industry has nothing but utmost contempt for tourists and will make sure you know that.
3. Scams. 80% of all Vietnamese you'll interact with will lie through their teeth in an attempt to extract money from you. If you don't play along, they'll get loud, insistent and aggressive. You can easily get ripped off in Thailand, which has ten times the return rate, but they usually do it with a smile and try to make sure you won't notice. Vietnam is on the level of people blatantly telling you to fuck off and demanding double while you point at the price list right behind them.
Don't take me wrong, Vietnam's my favorite place in SEA, but it is, without any doubt, a rude shithole that is the very opposite of comfy and that relaxed holiday feeling is what people are usually looking for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378776
This sounds about right.

You can make India as cheap or as expensive as you'd like. Personally, I think $50-60 per day is a good range for travelers who want to be reasonably comfortable and not have to constantly pinch pennies.

For about $50-60 per day, you can get:
>reasonably nice hotel room (2-3 stars) or Airbnb
>mix of street food and mid-range restaurant food
>private and public transportation (Uber+Metro)
>enough money to have a few drinks in the evening or on the weekends
>money for entrance fees and general sightseeing
>souvenirs and okay-quality handicrafts

You can obviously survive on much, much less money. If you're staying in a hostel dorm, for instance, you probably don't need more than $20-25 per day, assuming the dorm bed costs $8-10.

Fuck--you can basically live on $1-5 per day if you Couchsurf/stay in mosques/stay in gurudwaras and only eat street food. It's fucking India, most people outside of big cities are living on like $2-3 per day. Just don't expect that you can maintain a comfortable standard of living on these sorts of budgets.

However, I do think any strict budget of less than $20 per day is going to entail some significant sacrifices, especially for people who want to do adventure sports, visit a lot of monuments, etc. When you're spending closer to $50-60+ per day, you won't have the budget to stay in a 4- or 5-star hotel, but you can do pretty much everything else without having to think twice about your finances (within reason, of course).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378901
As a quick follow-up, if you're traveling in the country, money obviously goes a lot further. I regularly travel to East-Central India and stay in homestays. In one of the villages I frequent, there are like 2-3 different homestays. The rates are like:
>$7-8 per night for an entire mud house (sounds primitive but actually p comfortable)
>$3-4 per day for food (3 meals per day)
>$8-9 for a guide / someone to drive you around wherever you want (not necessary, but helpful if you want to visit hardcore ooga-booga areas etc)
>$3-4 per day for motorbike, fuel separate (I usually take my own bike)

so for about $20-30 per day, you have accommodation, transportation, and food completely covered

also worth bearing in mind that a lot of dirt-cheap hotels simply do not accept foreign guests, especially in smaller cities in rural areas. this has much less to do with xenophobia than local law, which requires anyone hosting a foreign national to submit a report (Form C) to law enforcement within 24 hours of the guest's arrival. most hotels just don't want to bother, since you have to create an account on the e-FRRO website and it takes like 10-20 minutes on a shitty internet connection to enter all the info

ofc, it's still india so you can accomplish just about anything with the right amount of money + patience

>>2324511
Neuquen is pretty much a big city now, isn't really that isolated, and has great landscapes.

Rio Negro is a bit more snowy, so naturally there's fewer urban areas, but still quite populated.

Chubut and Santa Cruz are pretty much full of industries and huge distances between every landmark. Would recommend it if you like isolation, snow and driving in it.

Otherwise, I would recommend Buenos Aires. You have the big city but there's also a lot of countryside to make your house there. About 100km you can choose exactly the amount of tranquility you're looking for depending on how far from tourist areas you want to go. Also, it's a lot cheaper to live there. Southern provinces are quite expensive. Pretty much the same as living in Europe.

posts.com:
Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Ask away if you wanna know anything about the people, climate, living standards, etc. of any particular province/region.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2328122
Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

>>2332641
>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

Why would you pay in another currency? You can exchange money at one of the countless exchange bureaus found in cities.
Since your Western card won't work, you'll have to bring cash or transfer your money to an account of yours in a non-Western bank to withdraw using Mir or UnionPay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2377560
I'm a corporate and legal services copywriter.

People here seem to think that copywriting pays pennies, but if you're a reasonably talented writer with a college degree and specific "niche," then you can make pretty good money doing very little work. Most of my clients pay between $100 and $200 for 1,000-page articles intended for lay audiences. Since I type about 150 words per minute and have years of experience, I don't have to do much research and can usually finish an article in an hour to an hour and a half.

Since I almost exclusively work with legal clients, the work is relatively dull--like I said, it's not something I want to continue doing indefinitely. In all probability, I'm going to apply for law schools and graduate programs next autumn. Even if I end up working more to make less money per hour, I'd rather be doing something that I find engaging and meaningful.

However, I do plan to retain 2-3 of my most stable clients which collectively pay about $35,000-$40,000 per year for less than 15 hours of work per week (e.g., one paid $12,000 in the last 12 months for about 3.5 hours of work per week; another pays exactly $12,000 per year for 3-4 hours of work per week; the other doesn't have a consistent assignment schedule, but probably pays around ~$15,000 per year for 4-5 hours of work per week).

IMO, it's a pretty decent gig, but you do generally need to met the following requirements:
>have at least a bachelor's degree (in any field, from a non-meme university)
>have prior paid writing experience
>have experience in a particular commercial niche (in my case law, but there's also decent money in grant writing, digital investments, B2B marketing, and medical copywriting)

To be perfectly clear, it took me years to start earning a sustainable, respectable income doing, but that's more my own fault than anything--I just sorted of treated writing as a side-gig when I was in university.

>>2379321
I don't get paid $200 per article. Instead, I said:
>Most of my clients pay between $100 and $200 for 1,000-page articles intended for lay audiences

For example:
>client 1 is a targeted blog that pays $30 per 500-word article, with each article taking 15-20 minutes to complete (I basically just re-write relevant news)
>client 1 requires that I write and publish exactly 10 articles per week (30*10*4*12 = $14,400 per year)
>client 2 is a personal injury law firm which pays $100 per 1,000-word article. Each article takes about an hour to write. The firm's content manager does revise and recommend edits, which usually take less than 5 minutes per article
>client 2 assigns a minimum of three articles per week ($300x4x12 = $14,400 per year)
>client 3 manages content for a personal injury law firm and its related asbestos litigation practice. This client pays $100 for 750-word articles, $130 for 1,000-word articles, and $200 for 1,500-2,000-word articles. These assignments usually take 1-2 hours to complete, depending on the subject and length. I am rarely asked to do any significant revisions
>client 3 assigns 3-4 articles every week, but can assign many more, depending on my availability and their demand (since most articles pay $130, we'll use that as the average. $130x3.5x4x12 = $21,840)

So, from these three clients, I earn--on average--about $50,640. The total writing time for these three clients is probably less than 15 hours per week. I don't keep track of revisions, because I'm ordinarily not asked to do anything beyond correct typos or insert [x] SE-optimized terms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2379334
I have other, clients, too:
>client 4 is a digital advertising company that works with many different companies in several different industries. I regularly write content for 4-5 different law firms, which receive anywhere from 1-6 posts per month. I usually work about ~3-4 hours for client 4, once per week
>client 4 pays between $50 and $100 per article (I'd average this, but I just asked that they provide a YTD summary of my earnings--about $12,000 and some change)
>client 5 is a friend's company, and this work has absolutely nothing to do with writing. I work between 1-2 hours per month and get paid $250 to click on boxes, insert digital signatures, and do basic calculations

That's about $65,000 per year for less than 20 hours of work per week. I have other, less reliable clients who don't provide regularly scheduled work. Putting it all together, I'd estimate that I average $75,000-85,000 per year.

In hindsight, I slightly under-exaggerated how much I work per week and slightly over-exaggerated my average monthly earnings. Realistically, I average between $5500 and $7500 per month. However, I do have months where I make ~$8,000+.

For something I don't do full-time and don't plan to continue doing indefinitely, I'm reasonably happy.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

Never been somewhere so romantic yet so shitty. Gritty, dirty big city, juxtaposed against a majestic, historic and captivating place full of winding old streets. Also beautiful girls, cheap whores and good food.

>Barcelona, Spain.
Not going to go down well on /trv/ but I’ve never had a bad vibe in this city. Big, cosmopolitan and international, modern yet loads of incredibly beautiful streets and neighbourhoods. Constantly has good events, great music/performance scenes and amazing restaurants/bars, imo some of the best in Europe.

In summer, Barcelona transforms into a sunny party city and attracts some of the most incredible women in the world and has one of the best party scenes in Europe.

One thing that I also like about Barcelona is the fact that it’s very much populated with normal, everyday Spanish people and families. Something that is pretty much lost on all of the other big international Western European cities.

Best

Zermatt, Switzerland
> did a massive circular route round the Alps one summer, starting and finishing at Geneva. Whole thing was spectacular. Zermatt was the peak. The Matterhorn is there; outstanding hiking everywhere; wonderful vibe; it's Swiss so everything works and is spotless; expensive so no riff raff. Dreamy.

Lofoten, Norway
> A string of craggy peaks in the high Arctic. the Gulf Stream means the winters aren't that bad and the summers, with 24/7 daylight, are unbelievable. Unforgettable hikes, stunning scenery everywhere you look. If you go in the winter the high latitudes mean the aurora is everywhere and the villages clinging to the edges of snow-dusted fjords are lovely.

NC 500, Scotland
> You take a car and drive around the extreme northwest of Great Britain. You don't just drive the NC500 itself like a retard you take detours to places like Skye and get the ferry over to Orkney. Allow at least two weeks. One of the world's greatest road trips.

>>2367779
>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

picrel from a bike trip I took in east-central india earlier this year (sorry for crappy angle, don't have anything better on laptop and too lazy to transfer from phone)

>Athens

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

In Athens the opposite of what is happening in most of the world is happening. Most the world has seen the city center being reclaimed by the rich and the professional yuppie class and their gentrifying, but in Athens the property market is the reverse, the city center is now a dump that is like an Islamic shitstain country and the outer areas of Athens are more expensive and sought after.

Finally this trip I spent much more time in the wealthier sections on the outer perimeter of Athens and the infrastructure still sucks, but it is nothing like the dystopia that is the Athens city center which is a mini Karachi or Dhaka at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373726
Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best
South Lake Tahoe. It's the most gorgeous place Ive ever seen. The lake is insane. Awesome outdoor bars. Amazing bike trails and hikes. But it still has a downtown area with a lot of good food and bars. Sitting around at the Hangar bar drinking beer by the fire at night under the stars is a vibe that's hard to match.

Jackson Hole Wyoming. The food is shockingly good. Every place in town is like a gourmet cowboy bar. You can do pretty much any outdoor outdoor activity. Whitewater rafting the snake river was one of the best experiences of my life. 3 days in Jackson Hole was not enough.

Maui. The best beaches Ive ever seen were in Makena on Maui. We found a condo for $300/night and that was a really good deal. I bought fresh fish a couple times and just grilled out to cut down on the outrageous restaurant bills we racked up. It's insanely expensive and we probably spent 4 grand on a 6 day trip for the 2 of us, but I felt like it was money well spent.

Worst
Portland Oregon. The memes are true. Portland is a homeless cesspool. There were homeless people camped out front of our Airbnb on a normal suburban street. It was one of the least charming cities Ive ever visited.

Atlantic City New Jersey. We parked the car and someone tried to sell us crack within 30 seconds. It's like vegas with none of the attractions but in the worst neighborhood you've ever seen.

Fresno California. You'll probably never go there, because why would you? I had to stay there for a conference. Your nightly choice of dining options are Dominoes Pizza, and a 24 hour McDonalds. It actually has worse crime than LA.There is literally NOTHING to do.

I’ve been to about 80 countries and I don’t think I genuinely hated any. Yeah there are up and downs but I have always found pleasant surprises. Some countries are better than others, for sure. Then there are countries I won’t really come back because I think I did most of it (tiny little ones).

Countries I liked the most:

- Iceland: did a multi-days trek in the middle of nowhere, in snowy volcanic landscape. Nothing is remotely similar.

- Extremadura in Spain, Yunnan in China in the early 00s, Chile, Lake Tahoe in Burgerland, some swampy place in Skåne Sweden (pic rel) etc. Too many things to list.

My latest trip was a road-trip in Netherlands. I liked it, I learned and saw a lot.
I love traveling so much bros.

>what has changed since 2019?
Forgot to answer this part. First in 2012, then far more substantially in 2019, the Chinese Communist Party forced the Hong Kong government to rewrite large parts of its legal framework (which was supposed to remain untouched until 2047) to align with Chinese law instead of the old British common law. Among other things, HK defendants can now be tried in Mainland China if the CCP demands it. It also purged the HK legislature of anyone who wasn’t fully sympathetic to the CCP.
>I thought they were dropping most of the covid regulations
Nope, just the mandatory quarantine period. Masks are still mandatory, even outside, and they still have a digital vaccine passport system in place with no end date in sight.

I went to a couple of spa weekends with my ex, which is nice, and I've stayed in a few nicer hotels mainly through work.

In general, it's worth it if you plan to use the amenities (spa, gym, bars lounge etc). However I've found it worth it to upgrade a room or get a suite. You end up with a slightly bigger, much more expensive room with a different bedspread.
I'd consider it worth it for like on-suite jacuzzi or panoramas but those suites are generally $1000+and I've never tried any.

So my recommendation if you want to try it is to get the cheapest kind of room.

Honestly, I've done it multiple times due to me organizing events in expensive hotels (they usually give me a suite since i'm bringing around a thousand people to that event per year). Honestly, the only moment it's worth it is if you're planning to splurge on obvious extras, such as going to the luxury hotel downstairs, getting room service, getting your clothes and shit cleaned up, not having to give a fuck about doing the bed, and having snacks and shit at the ready at the minibar (usually in the high roller suites like the presidentials they give you free shit and a lot of it gets included).

These services are not made for tourists. They're made for people who have to travel ALL the fucking time and become emotionally and physically exhausted by it (pilots, professors, execs, rich investors) and just can't have to go to every fucking local grocery store or restaurant to get what's needed because 1) they may not have the time and 2) they can't really be bothered. It's like the first class shit in airplanes where they get a few minutes of hot water. That's because the mfers are execs that probably will have a meeting around 3 hours from them landing and they don't want to look like they just had sex with a fat prostitute in the toilet a couple of minutes ago.

If you're a tourist literally anything is better than going at the fucking hotel except maybe if the restaurant is good. And EVEN then, why bother with a globohomo michelin star restaurant that you can have at home when you're in a totally different part of the world where you can try actual traditional family-made cooking.

If you really want a suite experience just to see what it feels like, just go to Vietnam. Fuck, even Taiwan where I lived had some pretty ridiculous prices for great hotels. I'm going to visit NYC (yes I know) for just under a week around mid Jan. Never been to the US before, so I want the full globohomo experience.

Currently I have:
- One day set aside for Central Park and associated sights/museums (AMNH, Mets)
- General admission to Ellis Island Museum of Immigration
Statue of Liberty (and will go on Staten Island Ferry). Are the Crown/Pedestal tickets worth it?
- Spend Chinese New Year in Chinatown and surrounding areas.
- UN tour and 9/11 museum.
- Times Sq, I'll buy a postcard from the stand in 30mins.
- Greenwich village for LGBTQIA+, Chelsea Market, Whitney Museum, and Little Island
- Grand Central Terminal. Is it actually worth it to go inside the Empire State Building/Rockefeller Centre if I'm not into selfies/shopping?
- Brooklyn Botanic Garden
- Carnegie Hall and watch a Broadway show

Any tips and recommendations for a Europoor please.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i like sightseeing etc, but only if its not too much hassle, what i like doing is researching what kind of foods are popular locally or what are some restaurants that stand out to me and then try to find them.

some nice food i had in manhattan:

if you are open to having a fairly expensive meal (not the most expensive in the city) a classic new york steakhouse is a good type of cuisine to try. i went to rocco steakhouse and it was great but i think if you look at a list of best ones there are a dozen or two higher. some famous ones i recall are keen's, gallagher's and peter luger

went to a new italian restaurant - nonna dora's pasta bar, they have an old italian grandma who still rolls the pasta. moderately priced (for nyc) but very amazing pasta - a main pasta dish is like 30$ here

good value tasty food in crappy restaurants: next to times sq is a hole in the wall cuban restaurant called margon - getting the cuban sandwich is worth it, but they have a hot counter of cuban food, or cafe bar also. I went on a saturday - i think weekdays its busy with lunch workers.

in chinatown, wah fung no 1 fast food is a cantonese bbq takeaway only (there is a park across the street if its far from your accomodation), you can get a large box of rice and pork/duck/chicken for good value and you'll see its been covered a lot on the internet. its another shitty looking hole in the wall, often has a line that moves fast one the few things i didnt mind waiting in line for.

but there are other things to seek out like a jew diner food, or classic nyc pizza vs fancy different style pizza, or some immigrant food you might not come across often
if you pick the more famous restaurants the higher chance of waiting in line if no reservations are possible. sometimes you can eat at the bar too remember. but waiting in line if you are excited and have anticipation for the food it may be fun, but if you are waiting to be impressed while waiting in line maybe not worth it.

gotta try Xian’s famous foods. Get the cumin lamb noodles. Delicious.

If you’re into bars, strangelove is a cool punk bar.

Check out the high line and the crazy looking new park near it called Little Island. It’s great. The Bronx zoo is cool too if you’re into that.

Rockefeller center has a better view imo, mainly because it has the Empire State in the skyline, but the empire states is cool too. Some neat King Kong memorabilia.

The evolution store has a bunch of weird shit to buy.

Mmuseumm is this cool tiny museum, you should check it out.

Going into the crown at the Statue of Liberty is cool but idk if it’s really worth it. Ellis Island is fascinating.

Also, if you have the time you should do a tour with this guy: the amount of shit he knows about New York is insane and he’s super cool. The only city tour I’ve ever done.
http://www.tomdelgado.net/tour-guide/

I just got back a few weeks ago. I’ve gone every December the past 6 years or so, but I think I’m gonna go in the spring this year. I wanna experience a warm New York

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2382545
italian american food has morphed into its own thing so i wouldnt outright dismiss it, but there are direct italian immigrants that if they can establish themselves in nyc they are pretty damn good, but i see your point. Just "italian" food is part of the last 120 years of american cuisine.

there are a lot of indian and pakistan places - there will be enough that they sometimes niche into their regional foods as does the chinese food.
there are also different asian cuisines like korea, japan, tibet, vietnam, thai as the most common. Caribbean food is great (well cuban is included in this but it is an offshoot, like jamaican or trinidad or haitian are all different, all very good), There will be a few african restaurants too if interested. Different types of arab food too. There will be some of every type of european cuisine almost.
If you were there for a short time it may be a waste, but if you were tehre for a while and getting fatigue of looking for new stuff - trying to find a restaurant of your home country cuisine could be fun, but always a risk of disappointing, and lost opportunity for new food.

while trying ethinic food is part of the appeal of nyc (for a westerner), indulging in classic american foods whether it is nyc origin or a regional type that has set up a restaurant there is still probably hte most exciting for you.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuisine_of_New_York_City

Family visa. Easiest one to get right now. You need to prove you’re related by blood + invitation letter by a relative. You’ll need a copy of their Chinese ID, letter, and I think something like birth certificate (for example, you’re the son of a Chinese-born mother who has a Chinese citizen sister, in this case you need to prove that your mom is the daughter of Chinese nationals + is affiliated with her sister by blood) linking up to said relative. It’s easy when you’ve done it several times in the past as everything is pretty much the same except the invitation letter that needs to get updated.

If you have all the papers ready, you can have it within a week at most. That’s how long it took when I did it for my mother’s visa application (she’s dumb with computers and booking appointments).
With family emergency, it might be a tad faster. But you’ll need a letter from some doctor or hospital to prove that it’s some emergency matter.

Also, iirc, you need a plane ticket before applying for visa (no more than 3 or 1 month before the flighh, cannot remember) however I cannot remember whether or not it’s mandaroty right now. Yes and no.
It has a lot of history (but it’s not that accessible and a lot of old things were destroyed during cultural revolution), it has great nature (if you can avoid overcrowded tourist-friendly places), it has good food. The country is very big and has a lot of different cultures.

It’s definitely not a very tourist-friendly destination. You’ll need a VPN, most information about China is in Chinese on Chinese websites, most of the Chinese people don’t speak English, cities are not easy to navigate in, and you need to tolerate a lot of bullshit such as Chinks skipping lines, spitting, shoving you because they have no respect for private space, their absolute shit driving etc. So usually people who hate it are not used to that bit of uncivilised wilderness left in China and more used to hand holding “tourist friendly” destinations.
But if it’s not your first country as a visitor and have some experience with bullshit, then yeah, it’s quite worth it.

Just remember to never get too personal over bullshit. Chinks have no sense of privacy, so they don’t always mean disrepect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

>Beijing
Huge roads, not walkable, shit public transport, gray, businesses mostly in big ass malls, shit nightlife (as in, night street food, night restaurants etc). Very restrictive so not many small things going on.

See Tokyo but more chaotic, friendlier, less autistic and more night things going on.

Classier and more orderly than Osaka. High-end culture.

A mix of the best of both worlds (Japan and China), reminiscent of Hong Kong in some ways but less chaotic, more laid back.

Only went there in the 90s. Not very interesting back then.

Very “cyberpunk”. Very rich and poor mingle together. Businesses everywhere, almost impossible to see darkness in the central parts. Closest you’ll get.

Discount Hong Kong with much much less life going on. Went there in the late 90s though.

>Chongqing
Memed by youtube videos. No idea why this city is brought up all the time. Many cities are similar to this one, part of the recent trend of newly invested cities such as Hangzhou.

>Shanghai
My personal favourite but not because of how “cyberpunk” it feels. It’s a city with a lot of life, good blend of modernity and (not so old) history.

Below Chios is Ikaria and I highly recommend it. The island has a wealth of things to do and so many beautiful villages, but is not touristy like Thira and Mykonos. There is a overwhelming sense of authenticity, not only because there are no gypsies to shove flowers at you. Make sure to visit the Afianes Winery in Raches, by Armenistis on the north coast. Armenistis also has great surfing and food. On the south coast is Agios Kirykos, its biggest town. There's another town in the mountains I'll post the name of later when I remember it. It might just be another part of Raches. Overall 10/10.

>>2378976
Nicaragua is a bit niche but was one of my favourite places in the Americas.
If you have time and want to check out the beaches head over to the corn islands.
You have 2 options you can either fly from Managua to big corn islands and then get a boat across (expensive but quick) or you can over land it, Managua to a place called blue fields, then a boat to big corn then another to little corn, I did it but got caught up in some sort of holiday and got stuck in blue fields for a few days - boring as hell but $1 hotel room was kino.
If you go to Colombia you have to go from Panama, overland is closed due to the FARC but they have an epic bait trip via the san blas islands which is epic.
Enjoy your trip!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2379345
You don’t have to speak Italian. Almost everyone speaks English. It’s to the point they recognized an American accent in my Italian and would immediately switch to English. They can spot Americans or Italians who have lived in the US for a while because we pronounce Italian words like Mexicans. Restaurants are a problem if you’re traveling solo as is feeling moody and lonely. Italians have this whole meal time cultural thing that makes it suck for people who are alone. Donerbabs and fast food are your friends. Moody and lonely just comes with the isolation of traveling alone if you aren’t good at meeting people. Keep busy looking at things. There’s a lot to see. Avoid nogs, rags, and zingari. You have to do Rome due to the amount of historical things to look at, but avoid nogs at all costs in that city and limit your time in the train station…just get in and get out. Rome is chaotic and very much a big city and tourist trap. Florence is going to be much better, much more laid back, with friendlier people. Pisa is a university town. Some of the smaller cities in the north are surprisingly pleasant. Genoa, Turin, etc. Bologna has been gentrified a lot. You can even walk Bolognina after dark these days even if the streets are surprisingly empty by 9 pm for an Italian city. The further south you go the more dysfunctional it gets but not in a dangerous way. That’s just northern stereotypes about the subhuman terrone (mostly true, but they are just dumb and lazy, not dangerous). Hotels will suck by American standards, even compared to a Holiday Inn express, so unless you want to know how to say Norman Bates in Italian it’s worth the money to go up a star or two. Inflation has hit hard and things are expensive there now. Be prepared for that. You get a mixture of competent and lazy as shit with Italians. If they don’t volunteer to do something then expect to just have to deal with it not being done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2379697
Florence will be good. They do free entry to Boboli gardens on some Sundays. The monastery or whatever up the hill has much better city views than the meme Piazzale Michelangelo. The kiosk near SMN across from the Burger King has good pork or cow intestine sandwiches. There is a nice cheap (for Italy) pizzeria up Nazionale just past the gelato place on the corner. Don’t waste money on the pajeet leather touts. There are a couple of legit store fronts run by Italians for that. Spend some time on the right bank of the Arno. Get up early and hit the big tourist sites in Rome before the crowds get there and then just wander. Try to go into every church you see if you’re into that sort of art. They are free to get into. There are also a bunch of meme fountains and shit. You have to pay to get into a lot of the historical sites. Near the big ugly TV screen on Cavour go down the stair case with the mural and you’ll find a bunch of narrow streets with restaurants and stuff. Use the Republicca metro station passageways to cross the street around that big clusterfuck instead of braving the crosswalks. Buchetto is a good sandwich place on Viminale. Borghese is a good park. Wander through Ludovisi and the area west of Porta Pia outside of the walls. If you go north just before Porta Pia inside the old walls you’ll find a small communist neighborhood with a lot of left wing nose ringed teenagers loitering around to try to sex up. Also they can be found loitering outside the old walls south of Pia Porta. The age of consent in Italy is 15. Also most Italian women stink and are ugly. Enjoy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nogs hang around the tourist sites and will act like they are going to give you a high five, then grab your arm and try to tie a string bracelet to it and demand that you pay for it. Just scowl at them and keep walking. If they do force a bracelet on you, just steal it without paying. They’ll ooga booga a bit but they are there illegally and don’t want police attention so they’ll fuck off. You’ll get white people trying to get you to sign petitions. Just scowl, pretend you don’t speak English, say something in Russian, and keep walking. If it’s an attractive woman you can use the opportunity to try to sex her up (they are Italians usually, not slavs or zingari) but don’t sign and don’t give money. They aren’t pushy, and I’m not sure if they are real petitions or just a scam but I don’t care either way. Zingari you just stare at like you want them dead and keep moving. Make sure they know you hate them. They are subhuman scum. Arabs and pajeets will be minding their own business except for the rags around Termini who might try to pickpocket. Pickpockets are only a problem in train stations or if you get into a heavy crowd in a major tourist area. It’s gotten a lot better in Rome lately. The zingari will send little kids to do it because they can’t be jailed so be prepared to kick an 8 year old in the face if necessary. Don’t feel bad. They aren’t human and the police don’t really care what you do to them. Overall it’s not nearly as bad as it used to be, though.

Rome has some unwritten traffic and pedestrian rules. Watch the Italians, not the tourists, around you and do what they do when crossing streets.

Nobody gives a fuck. If you really are scared to look strange for some dumb reason, go to a pub that serves food, and eat food at the counter. This is what I usually do when the place seems crowded.

Learn some basic words and sentences you midwit. If the place is english-friendly, then just talk normally, if not, just limit yourself to basic sentences and words. Learn some (“can I eat here”, “water”, etc), it takes a few minutes.
