Who visits every attraction?

I went to Washington DC last year. To visit all those I would imagine it would take well over a week, rushing through museums and racing through monuments and very careful planning, plus skipping meals. But you will get fatigued of visit museums and monuments after 2-3 days like a tourist robot doing what other tourist robots do and pretending to be cultured and caring about museum and attractions. Washington DC has some cool parks closeby I would recommend checking one or two out to break up the monotony of gawking at buildings, monuments and going to museums.

A shocking number of those museums require you to actually book a ticket in advance of your visit. I think the Spy Museum which I definitely wanted to visit fell under that category. I think the African American museum also did.

If you are not there with a car, I would recommend to rent the bikes they have, their equivalent of NYC's Citibike, I forgot what they call their network. There are stations near every major monument and it will save so much time compared to walking and so much money compared to cabs or renting a car.

You don’t need to visit every spot on that map, there are some major museums to hit, a tour of the Capitol, Arlington Cemetery, and some beautiful neighborhoods to visit, and you can do all that in a few days at a leisurely pace.

Sadly, some of the best parts of the DC area are not in the city proper (Glenstone Museum, Rockville and Falls Church asian food, etc), and the locally grown culture of the city is pretty inaccessible to tourists because it is meant for native Black DC residents.

Come to DC, do the generic things and knock them off your list, go out to bars in Adams Morgan (full of students), 14th Street (full of millennial professionals networking), U Street (very Black) or H Street NE (some neat spots, very black). But don’t try to dig too deep, the people who live here live to work, and they usually won’t give you the time of day unless you work in an advantageous field (or are Black).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2378955

For future reference OP, a lot of the German insurers will offer global health coverage (Auslandskrankenversicherung) for around €10-20 a year as an add-on. You can also often add travel insurance (Reiseversicherung) to your home insurance for like a euro a month in some cases. There's no need to buy separate policies each time you go abroad as in the UK and it works out a lot cheaper too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380589

Just to clarify, in Germany these are two separate kinds of insurance. Auslandskrankenversicherung covers health stuff, Reiseversicherung covers flight cancellations etc. The first one is always a must, the second I'd only get for certain kinds of trips.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380593

Another tip, the travel health insurance policies you sometimes get with German credit cards are usually dogshit as they usually don't cover a lot of important things like medical evacuation. Don't rely on them, always get proper global cover.

Echoing >>2378991...
It's easy for your company to cut their losses and terminate your employment.
-You're new.
-You haven't proven performance.
-You've demonstrated poor judgment
-The next in line/runner up of the interview process will get your job.

>>2378909
Beware: Don't do it.

1) You've landed a new job, and you're positioning things like you're fortunate.
Thailand or not, why ruin a good thing without any plans/framework?

2) Review your contract.
I doubt there's anything in your contract about needing to work within X distance from your office in case RTO is announced, but that leads me to...

3) Ask your new colleagues.
Stealthily inquire about their current work situations. Understandably, you'll have to ask peers who are in a similar role/scenario as you.

4) Ask your supervisor/manage if you can work from the next time zone over (Say you're helping your wife's boyfriend after they were discharged from the hospital) and see what their reaction is like.

5) Test your technical restrictions.
Internet connections come in different shapes and sizes. This is made tricky/worse with longer distances introducing more hops/latency/blah
Depending on how your VPN is connected, your access might stick out like a sore thumb, and you'll be found out in less than a day.

>>2378909
Any decent sized company will have a security operations team (SoC) who will be monitoring where people log in from
I'm assuming you'll need to connect to your company VPN to actually do your work so they will find out, when I popped over to Spain for a couple of weeks the SoC messaged me asking me to confirm where I am just so they knew the laptop hadn't been stolen
Once I explained they were fine with it and told me to just let them know if I'll be working abroad in the future

Your company WILL have a remote working policy, check the documentation and it'll give you an insight into your options. It could say you have to work within your country of employment or, like mine, could be more lax and say words to the effect of "it's the responsibility of the employee to work out tax ect in regards to where they work from"

In any case if you've JUST started this job I'd give it half a year to establish yourself and get past your probation period before you do this

Before COVID happened and remote working became mainstream, this used to be pretty common. Most companies didn't know/care about the legal implications of having people working from other places. I did it a bunch pre-COVID-- including for longer time periods. After COVID, I'm with a new employer (in finance industry), and I've done it, but it's been for shorter times, and I've been more sneaky about it (i.e. not telling anyone I was working from abroad). My advice would be to go for it, but you should shouldn't tell anyone, and you should give your employer plausible deniability by using a VPN. When you set up the VPN, do not set it up on the laptop. Set it up on the router that the laptop connects to. Buy a dedicated router for this. Good luck! Have fun!

If you have a work vpn or if it’s a big company and they have geo blocking configured on their Microsoft accounts you will be pretty fucked.
I tried this earlier this year and got abroad only to find out I couldn’t even login to my work outlook email without being on a vpn with my region set to the US. This worked for my Microsoft account but we also have a company VPN for accessing internal sites and data, this is what fucked me. Couldn’t get on it even with my personal VPN connected as well, the company VPN could tell I was tunneling through another and rejected my connection attempts. I ended up having to play dumb and ask my boss if he was cool with me working abroad for awhile after I had already gotten there. Luckily he was but our info sec team still bitched about it constantly cuz they have to whitelist IPs for me (which constantly change unless you can get a static one, which will be nearly impossible abroad).
Long story short, if you do all of your work through Microsoft or gmail email you might be fine, if you have a company VPN you are probably fucked and will have to come clean. If that’s the case I would probably tell them ahead of time rather than look like a dumbass and go without telling them hoping they don’t fire you.

>>2379415
They probably want to make sure you're not using a satellite internet connection of a 3G dongle or something. A RPi should be okay. The RPi can connect to wifi wherever you are, and you can connect to the RPi via a wired connection. The RPi can then route your traffic through a VPN. You should, of course, test this before you go.

I don't know what your work setup looks like, but I suspect that latency will be more of an issue than bandwidth. The extra 100-200 ms of latency to go from one side of the world to the other might be problematic.

Technical things aside, have you thought about the time difference? If your job is on the east coast, you'll have a 12 hour time difference if you're in Thailand. I did six hours time difference for a while, and there were occasional annoyances, but I can't imagine how annoyed I would be if I had to sit through a mandatory HR training from 3 AM to 4 AM on a Saturday morning.

>>2380169
To make a long story short, it has to do with tax liability and cybersecurity. If you live more than 6 months in most countries, that means you have to pay taxes to them, and most companies can't be bothered to deal with this for you. Many companies will turn a blind eye, but financial services companies are especially careful about this.

Cybersecurity is a concern when moving around abroad, as you may be accessing and transmitting sensitive data on an insecure network. You can't know if the WiFi in that random hole in the wall cafe in Venice you've taken your laptop to is properly secured. Also, many companies will track where you're accessing stuff from, to watch out for poojeet and Russian hackers. This is also why companies with half a brain won't let you log in to company networks from VPNs.

Russian hackers are like modern day privateers; their government gives them de facto permission to wage low-intensity warfare on America by theft, so lots of unscrupulous people have the opportunity to make fortunes they wouldn't have anywhere else. They aren't prosecuted for going after American companies, so we have to remain vigilant about where people are accessing our infrastructure from.

You could have avoided all of this with just a >>2379403 travel router..

1. Get a VPN based out of your home country and use it while working there to test the waters.
2. Then just connect your hotel WIFI abroad to the travel Router (connected to your home VPN)
3. Connect your work laptop t the travel router and then to your work VPN.

Boom problem solved, all that the "security" team are going to see is you connecting from the same VPN you've been using months prior.

>>2381243
>Explain how a travel router would even login to company intranet VPN.
The travel router doesn't log in to company VPN. The travel router logs in to another VPN service that has an exit point in the US. Then, your laptop connects to the travel router, which tunnels all traffic through the VPN, and your laptop connects to work VPN. Work sees you VPN connection as coming from the US.

posts.com:
>>2381584
If you know what you're doing you can stand up your own VPN server on Linode, or Digital Ocean, or OVH, or whatever people like to use. Depending on provider, there might even be pre-configured appliances you can deploy. It requires a bit of knowledge, but you'll get a static IP, and, in my experience, it's faster and cheaper than commercial VPN service.

A typical VPN service, whether its commercial or your own server running somewhere, is still going to have a non-residential IP address. A really strict company could complain about that.

If you have family or friends back home who you trust, you could convince them to use a router that supports running a VPN server (and probably also some dynamic DNS service, so you don't lose it if the address changes).

Alternatively, you could ask them to host a Raspberry Pi (or similar) on their network and run the VPN server there. Tailscale would be a really easy solution for this and avoid the need to deal with NAT or DNS. See: https://tailscale.com/kb/1103/exit-nodes/

If you wanna visit a comfy town, you can take the ferry from Batangas to Romblon. The town is fairly small, yet charming. Just a short motorcycle-ride away, you got Bonbon beach which is usually quite pristine, and you also have Logbon island just a short boat-ride away.

Besides, this is the marble capital of the country, so you can buy nice marble figures and misc. for quite cheap. There's also an Italian restaurant there ran by an actual Italian with pizza that tastes quite good considering the logistical implications of running it there.
Although the island is quite small, you can take a small ferry to Tablas which has lot's of nice beaches around and some outdoor activites, or to Sibuyan which is less developed but has a 2,000m mountain that is quite challenging to hike(takes 2 days), so if hiking is your thing, check that one out. Also Cresta de Gallo is one of my favourite islands.

That's Inambakan in Southern Cebu. Very nice falls consiting of 3 levels. However, not too far away is also Dao Falls(pic related) which is much more majestic, and requires a 30min trek along the stunning river that leads up to it. Almost straight out of a fairytale.
To get to either of these, you can avail of either a tour agency in Moalboal, or if you are not a complete retard on a scooter, you can rent one and go by yourself.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
In Bohol, go to Dimiao. There are 4 popular waterfalls there, and it's quite far so barely any tourists there either. You may come accross Kuya RJay, the tour guide there. He's pretty cool and fun. Tell him you hate Russians and he will love you.
If you have time, check out Anda Beach, pretty nice. Also it's close to Cam-Umantad falls and some kino rice terraces.
DON'T RIDE IN THE DARK YOU ARE PLAYING WITH THE DEVIL IF SO. And I'm not talking about getting robbed, I am talking about the traffic hazards, like poorly lit roads that could have obstacles in them that you can't see, borderline psychopathic bus and van-drivers, dogs suddenly running accross the road infront of you.

>>2373189

>Loboc river seems interesting but I've heard mixed reviews about river cruise
It's cool to do once, but that's about it. There are some paved roads that go along the river or close to it so you can check out through that.

>Also chocolate hills and tarsiers... is it crowded and touristy?
Barely any tourists in the Tarsier Sanctuary last time I was there. Be sure to go early.
Chocolate Hills can get quite crowded. However, there's a "secret" area though that you can go to. You can climb ontop of one of the hills there right by the road and have a great view. Pic related
Not too far from the Chocolate Hills there's something called Pangas Falls.

>Also places for food/entertainment, I will try anything.
In Cebu City, check out 8flix & Chill. There they serve Tuslob Buwa. To spoil it for you, it's basically pork brain mixed with chili, onion and onions sauce. It turns into a gravy which you dip "puso", or rice balls in. As disgusting as it might sound to most, it's actually really good. Imagine dipping bread in a buttery gravy full of umami. That's pretty much what it is. It's dirt cheap too, $4 for 10 piece of rice balls and unlimited gravy.
Top of Cebu is another nice restaurant to check out.

In Bohol, Mist is a cool interesting restaurant made in the vernacular style. Molly Bistro is similar, though they primarily serve a Filipino/Viet BBQ fusion.
Bamboo place is usually where the nightlife is in Alona/Tawala.
Be on the lookout for Beefarm Ice cream along Alona Beach. Really delicious. And on that topic, The Buzzz Cafe is pretty nice. Check out Halang Halang, a Bisaya soup similar to Tom Kha Gai.

If you go to Balicasag, don't fucking eat anything there. I am an advocate for promoting Filipino food and even I found the food there very mediocre. Also it's a ripoff, $10 for a single plate of an awful meal. If they still sell barbecue in Virgin Island, I suggest you to avoid the touts. It's good but extremely overpriced.

Cont.

>>2373197

>Worth it to rent motorbikes everywhere or is it dangerous?
If you have common sense, you'll be fine most likely. Don't drive like a maniac, get used to the bike first. Don't do steep turns(if you know how to truly countersteer) if there is dust or dirt on the road. Keep an eye on the rear mirrors. If you see a van, bus or any big car approaching you fast, steer to the right shoulder to let them pass. These drivers have no brains, but you don't want them to harm you either.
Before you rent a bike, check that both the front and rear brakes are good, that means you shouldn't have to squeeze/press them too hard to actually stop. Check for air in the tyres, they should be rock hard.
Ask the renters to check oil.
Honk whenever you are passing someone, or think someone who is at perpendicular interchange haven't seen. Use the horn alot to let people know you are there.
Bohol and Siquijor are great places to rent. Coron you won't really need.

>Any way to avoid food poisoning or should I just bring Cipro and pray?
I honestly think it all depends on your gut most of the time. I've been food poisoned here a few times but that was after staying here for many months. Meanwhile, my friend and his gf was here for only 4 days and they both got food poisoned, but not me. But yeah, you are likely to experience some kind of diarrhea sooner or later

cont.

>Any other tips/advice for Philippines I'd appreciate.
Use Grab when going around in the cities. Taxi drivers in this region is notorious for ripping people off, although I ironically had no problem using Taxis in Cebu City, the 3 drivers were honest and used a non-rigged meter.
A 10min ride with tricycle should not cost more than P150-200. If they say anything above, haggle or just go for another driver.
Don't be swayed by touts, be on the look for the best deal. If you can't find, give in to them and hear what they offer.
Ignore hawkers unless they have something you really need and can't acquire easily in that moment, eg. drybag.
I suggest you learn how to use the "tabo" when taking a shit. It will save you space not having to bring rolls everywhere.
Don't be afraid to ask locals for directions.
There are probably more stuff but I can't recall much right now.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
About Coron, if you have time and money, do a Dugon tour. It's one of my favourite activites I've ever done. Contact this guy for more info:
https://www.instagram.com/freedivewithlouie/

There are also alot of Japanese shipwrecks there from WWII that are worth to check out if you have your scuba cert in place. I think they will only let you dive in the cargo ship as it's very easy to traverse.

>>2376440
It’s more of an /out/ country in my opinion. Lot’s of neat outdoor activities you can do such as hiking, canyoning, scuba diving(BIG emphasis on this one), free diving, surfing, expedition tours, island hopping. Night life can be fun here aswell.
Culture-wise, many will tell you they are Mexicans of Asia, but I rather think they have a maritime Asian culture. Lot’s of emphasis on sea-faring in a tropical climate, with a few Asian elements here and there, and also a few Spanish elements.
In my opinion, the most glaring American influence is in the language, brutalist architecture, basketball, (barely functional) political structure, urban planning and some food items the mutts unfortunately introduced. Reggae is also quite popular in the sea-side communities due to this.
If you’re American(Fil-Ams are notoriously bad at cooking) give the country’s cuisine atleast one more chance by dining in well-regarded establishments such as Manam and Gerry’s Grill. It has potential unironically, but the average flip puts no soul into it.

And if you think their language is bad, oh boi don’t visit any of the countries with tonal languages or else you will have an aneurysm lmao

Cont.

> I do like photography and fishing, for what it's worth.
This country is amazing for fishing, and has plenty of kino landscapes.
Spear-fishing is a very fun and super-rewarding activity to get into. It’s one of my favourite things to do.
If you prefer to stay on land, you still have massive fishing opportunities to catch plenty of exotic fish which crowd the surrounding seas.

Besides historically speaking, there are heaps of old shipwrecks around, some of them from WWII. Old Spanish buildings and forts are found around the whole island, and while there are some pre-colonial buildings and slight remains of ruins in the country, they are in areas I would not suggest you to visit on your first trip.
And lastly, the country has some of the finest beaches in the world in my opinion.

Lol saw the thread and thought immediately of Romblon and lo there was the first post. I'll add this though: somewhere near Romblon you don't need to go is Sibuyan island. At the time I had a gf with friends of her family owning a villa at the island that they let us borrow (they wanted her parents to build something there as well). The island itself is very boring. A wildlife sanctuary - there are apparantly tons of unique or endangered birds there. There's basically no soil though, so most foodstuffs are imported by the same 24h ferry and there's not much available (and it's overpriced). The locals grow some rice and a few tomatoes from what I can recall.

Barely any sand beaches (if any) either. There's a waterfall though. Small island as well with a few villages all along the coastline. One resort (closed) and no restaurants or the like. In the evenings you can play basketball or do karaoke with the locals.

What is cool though, is the marble. It's so plentiful alot of stuff is built by it. Like the house we stayed in had a solid marble staircase and pillars because they were made on site. Do go to Romblon though.

1) Most: I really loved Japan, Scotland, and Sri Lanka. There's a ton to do in Japan, and Tokyo and Osaka are awesome cities. I know it has a reputation, but for Scotland, Glasgow is a very nice city. People were very nice, architecture was beautiful, lots of music and art all over. Sri Lanka was fun to explore, especially the northern, non-tourist areas.

Least: Cambodia is kind of a sleazy shithole, especially Phnom Penh.

2) Lots of wild adventures in Senegal, that was a lot of fun, but it helped that I had good people with me. Japan was fun, I liked clubbing there with friends.

3) Best food was Georgia, with Japan at a close second. Georgia has great flaky pastries, and khachapuri is awesome. Also good alcohol. Japan has great sushi, seafood, and fast food. Worst was Scotland lol, it's one of my favorite countries ever but I couldn't believe how bad most of the food in Scotland was.

4) I wouldn't mind living in Scotland, Japan, or Sri Lanka. I would never want to live in Cambodia. I would also probably avoid Turkey, people can be a bit aggressive and belligerent.

5) Favorite: Glasgow, Scotland; Austin, TX (great music city); Osaka, Japan.
Least: Phnom Penh, Cambodia
